NewsLines.HeadLine: AFRICA FX WEEKAHEAD-Kenya shilling set to slide further
NewsLines.CopyrightLine: (c) Copyright Thomson Reuters 2011. Click For Restrictions. http://about.reuters.com/fulllegal.asp

NewsLine.NewsLineText: AFRICA-CURRENCY/:AFRICA FX WEEKAHEAD-Kenya shilling set to slide further

body.p: NAIROBI, March 10 (Reuters) - Kenya's shilling is likely to fall even further into record territory next week unless the central bank decides to halt its dramatic slide by selling dollars. Uganda's shilling is also seen under pressure.
KENYA
The shilling <KES=> is likely to fall further after hitting an all-time low due to the rising cost of fuel imports and a stated policy of non-intervention from the central bank.
Commercial banks quoted the currency of east Africa's biggest economy at 84.15/25 to the dollar -- its lifetime low -- compared with last Thursday's close of 83.05/15.

"We are in uncharted waters. Anything is possible. If demand remains unabated and the sentiments for a weaker shilling remain, nothing will stop it from hitting 85.00," said Chris Muiga, senior trader at Kenya Commercial Bank.

The central bank stayed out of the foreign exchange market on Thursday. Its stated policy throughout the shilling's dramatic six-week slide is not to intervene unless it sees speculation driving the currency in either direction.
"The feeling is that central bank does not have enough reserves to intervene, but what are the reserves for? According to me, they are to stabilise exchange rates," Muiga said.
Central bank Governor Njuguna Ndung'u said on Wednesday intervention was not an option.
"Intervention always signals uncertainty which, on one hand, leads to speculation or on the other hand puts true investors into a wait-and-see mode," he said in a statement.
Traders said rising global oil prices due to turmoil in Middle East and North Africa had made Kenyan oil importers jittery.

"Oil importers are forward covering on fear that oil prices in the international market would keep rising. This has pressured the shilling further," said Sameer Lagadia, head of trading at Diamond Trust Bank.
Traders said they expect the shilling to trade in the 84.00-84.80 range against the dollar into next week.
The shilling has dropped 10 percent against the dollar over the last 12 months and 3 percent over the last 12 sessions. Charts put it in a long-term downtrend. [ID:nLDE71R0ZE]
UGANDA

Uganda's shilling <UGX=> is expected to weaken towards a record low, hurt by dropping dollar supplies from aid organisations. Central bank dollar sales are not expected to have much effect on the foreign currency squeeze.
Commercial banks quoted the unit at 2,380/2,385 to the dollar versus last Thursday's close of 2,369/2,374.
"Most inflows that I monitor come from non-governmental organisations but lately there's been a significant drop from that source," said Faisal Bukenya, head of market making at Barclays Bank Uganda.

He forecast the shilling would trade in a narrow range of 2,380 - 2,400 in the week ahead. The unit hit a record low of 2,395/2,400 in late January amid jitters about a February presidential election that passed off largely without incident.
Analysts said falling dollar proceeds arose from diminishing export earnings from food and coffee exports.
The Bank of Uganda sold an undisclosed amount of foreign exchange on Thursday, but does not appear to have a target level in mind.

"Bank of Uganda doesn't wait for any particular level to intervene. What it doesn't want is extreme volatility which happened between yesterday evening and today morning," Bukenya said. "In that short period the shilling lost 10 shillings."
The currency's 14-day and 50-day simple moving averages show the shilling staying on a weakening trend in the short run.
In the last 12 months, it has lost more than 15 percent against the dollar.
TANZANIA
Tanzania's shilling <TZS=> may ease slightly due to foreign investors wishing to repatriate dividend payments.
Commercial banks quoted the local currency at 1,510/1,515 compared with 1,513/1,518 a week ago, and traders said it should trade in a 1,510-1,520 trade in the days ahead.

"We are heading towards the end of the first quarter. Most of the corporates are more concerned about making their first quarter tax payments at the moment," said Bruno Ngooh, a trader at Standard Chartered Bank Tanzania.
Traders said the central bank had been active, selling an average of $8.7 million each day.
"The shilling should remain in the same levels until the end of the month, but it could weaken next month when some companies start to pay dividends to offshore shareholders," Ngooh added.
The shilling is down nearly 12 percent against the dollar over the last 12 months, but is trading off a four-month low of 1,518 hit in late February.
Between last Thursday and Wednesday, the central bank traded $42.8 million on its Interbank Foreign Exchange Market, its website said.
NIGERIA
The naira <NGN=D1> could weaken further towards 155.00 to the U.S. dollar amid strong demand for the greenback from bureaux de change outlets and dwindling inflows from energy multinationals.

The naira was at 154.67 early on Thursday, compared to 154.36 at Wednesday's close, with more demand coming from some lenders funding bureaux de change outlets and covering unmet demand at the central bank's bi-weekly forex auction.
At the official window on Wednesday, demand outstripped supply, with the central bank coming up $70 million short, putting further pressure on dollars at the interbank market.
"The naira should depreciate further in the next couple of weeks until there are inflows from the energy companies," one dealer said.
Increased demand for dollars at the official auction came from gasoline importers placing orders for their next shipments of fuel into the country, traders said.
Nigeria's foreign reserves rose 8.6 percent to $36.38 billion from the end of February to March 8, increasing the ability of Africa's top energy producer to support its currency.
Dealers said the bureaux de change pressure could mean some individuals building up a stock of dollars in case of political trouble in the run-up to an April election.

"Most corporate institutions are not buying dollars at the present level because they prefer to pass their bids through the official window. It's the informal sector that is driving the current high demand," another dealer said.
"The naira should trade around 155 to the dollar by next week unless there is a large inflow of dollars."
The naira spiked to a record low of 158 against the dollar in early 2009 after a sharp depreciation from around 118 caused by the global financial crisis.
GHANA
The cedi <GHS=> is likely to stay range-bound, but with a slight weakening bias.
The unit was at 1.5205/30 to the dollar on Thursday, stronger than its record lows beyond 1.57 but weaker than the mid 1.40s it enjoyed for much of last year.

"I expect the trend to continue. We see very firm corporate demand in the coming week and the supply side is weak," said Jacob Brobbey from Barclays Ghana's treasury department. "The rate is gradual so it won't cause too much alarm for policymakers."
Access Bank's Biggles Amponsah said the cedi should ease slightly as companies in manufacturing and consumer import sector bought dollars to pay for bills fall due at the end of the first quarter.
"I expect the cedi to trade at around 1.5240 next week," he said.
ZAMBIA
The kwacha <ZMK=> may come under pressure due to resurfacing concerns about European debt souring sentiment to riskier emerging market securities.
Commercial banks on Thursday quoted the currency of Africa's top copper producer at 4,740 versus 4,715 a week ago.
"We expect the kwacha to be under pressure around 4,740-4,800 mainly because of the debt crisis in Europe," one trader said.
Standard Chartered said the kwacha would stick around 4,750 for the first of half of the year before pushing towards a key support resistance level of 4,650 in the second half.
The kwacha should benefit from buoyant copper prices, a trade surplus, rising foreign direct investment, low inflation, low interest rates and high foreign exchange reserves, the bank added.
Zambia's currency met firm resistance around 4,600 during 2010. On the few occasions it breached that level, it went on to test but failed to breach 4,550.
(Reporting by Oludare Mayowa, Kevin Mwanza, George Obulutsa, Elias Biryabarema, Fumbuka Ng'wanakilala, Chris Mfula and Hereward Holland, Compiled by Ed Cropley; Editing by Ron Askew)
